topic_rationale: Polycythemia vera is a classic myeloproliferative disorder that has a unique set of diagnostic criteria. Understanding these features can help with early detection, management, and prevention of complications.

explanations.tile_0: Elevated hematocrit is a defining characteristic of Polycythemia Vera.
explanations.tile_1: JAK2 mutation is present in 95% of Polycythemia Vera cases, confirming the diagnosis.
explanations.tile_2: Pruritus, especially after a warm bath, is a common symptom of Polycythemia Vera due to increased histamine release by basophils.
explanations.tile_3: Erythromelalgia, or burning pain and redness of the extremities, is a common symptom in Polycythemia Vera due to increased blood viscosity and platelet activation.
explanations.tile_4: Splenomegaly occurs in Polycythemia Vera due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.
explanations.tile_5: Low erythropoietin (EPO) levels help distinguish primary from secondary polycythemia. In Polycythemia Vera, EPO levels are low or normal despite high red cell mass.
explanations.tile_6: Thrombosis history is common in Polycythemia Vera due to increased blood viscosity and platelet activation.
explanations.tile_7: Hypercellular bone marrow with panmyelosis is seen in Polycythemia Vera.
explanations.tile_8: Increased neutrophils and other granulocytes are seen in Polycythemia Vera due to uncontrolled proliferation of all three myeloid cell lines.
